displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Uh. Clinical study? (Pause5sec) Patient: My one meds is I wasn’t so sure that I could take. Doctor: So, yeah, when we saw you, you already had Abiraterone, enzaluta – Radium, docetaxel. And, so what we do next, uh, you know, the only thing you haven’t had is, uh, chemotherapy. Uh, another chemotherapy called Radia, uh – Jevtana, cabazitaxel would be standard treatment you could go through, and we were waiting because again, you’d finished your chemo – um, and uh Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Um. So, uh. Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that. Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. We have to use the generic name. The, the drug company, they want the one that they want -- the fancy name. Um. So (Pause) Patient: Well, uh, the gentleman, M_, said he had one more chemo for me, but he didn’t have much faith it would do anything. So, maybe it was the same. Doctor: Well, it is – you never know until you try. Patient: Yeah. Okay.

Patient: That’s him. Doctor: We got him here. Patient: Oh he’s here now. Doctor: He’s here now. So he’s the go-to guy to get that process through. It goes through his group. Okay? So my suggestion is that we just have a discussion with him about side effects and pros and cons and what not as the next step. In the meantime you’re taking more pain medicine, right? Regularly. Family Member: I can’t – he’s like a little child “time for your medicine, are you going to take it?” Doctor: I know. Patient: Well I mean is there a benefit to taking the pain medication? Doctor: Yeah, you’d be more functional. Patient: Well I’m functionable. Family Member: But you’re in pain. Patient: Well then I also feel that if I’m masking the pain too much, then I’m overextending myself. Or maybe I shouldn’t be. Doctor: Oh well, set your activity level and don’t exceed it.

Patient: Because he went on to say he says in that area… Doctor: Um hum. Patient: …and we probably will be looking at some radiation. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And you know me, or like anyone, you’re going through the chemo and stuff like that you want… Doctor: Yeah. You’re like whaaaat? Patient: You want the golden ring man. Doctor: I got ya. Patient: You want that stuff to be doing everything it’s supposed to do. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Well it is doing everything it’s supposed to do because if you look at your lymph node, remember the bones hardly ever change. Patient: Right. Doctor: So whether it’s up or down, I just want to know if it’s new.

Patient: Uh, is difficult because I wake up in the morning, and I can feel some pain, strain or whatever. Uh, it’s strange that when I go and I had the two blood transfusions, that I could be on that table for five hours, laying on my back, and I don’t have no problem. I don’t know what the correlation that is. I tried to lift the bed up, and, uh, the, uh, the foot part, and I guess I haven’t found the, uh, the right position yet for it, for me that, that works. Uh, the, uh, but for the most part, we’ve been, we’ve been working through it. Doctor: How many oxycodone are you taking now? Patient: Uh. Doctor: Looking at this list. Patient: Well, my son did that. You know? He’s military. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today.

Patient: Right. Doctor: You take it twice a day. That doesn’t do the job? You take it three times a day. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: Okay? Morning, noon, and night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So that, so that’ll cover that. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Do I still get the prune juice and all that shit or not? Doctor: If you – well, you may not need it. Patient: I may not need it. Okay. Okay. So, we’ll just try the pills first. Doctor: Yes. And then you keep goin’ with your pain medicine –

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? Patient: That’s good. That’s good. I’m going to keep the faith that everything is, is good. Doctor: Okay. Now very good. (pause7sec) Patient: I try not to worry. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Don’t worry. Patient: Worry. You know? Because that, that’s, that’s bad. Doctor: That’s very bad. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yes. You don’t want to do that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stress can cause a lot of problems with the rest, other parts of the body.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So technically your ARV7 right now is positive enough to go on, your PSA is rising, you’re on the Xtandi, okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The worry is the lungs, okay because this is a treatment that if we turn on your immune system so loud it can attack your normal body. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So you can get a non-infectious pneumonia and get really short of breath and it fills up with scar tissue and s tuff like that and that we have to stop with steroids. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So if you have one of those gasping things, if it’s your old gasping problem or is it the new drug? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So then we’re going to put you on steroids and stuff like that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It can attack your colon so then you can have just profuse, non-stop diarrhea and so that we have to stop as well. It can attack your liver so then you get a hepatitis-

Patient: No. It won’t be a couple of months. We couldn’t handle a couple of months. Doctor: Okay. We’ll shoot for less than a month. How about that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. How you doing on the XTANDI? Not too bad? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. You look great. But anything compared to last time when you weren’t feeling so hot and your blood sugar was…… YOU LOOK GREAT! (Laughs) Patient: Well, I feel good. Doctor: Okay. We’ll have to see what your PSA is but obviously last time it’s gone down, and I’m thrilled. Patient: Well, let’s hope it’s gone down. So we haven’t gotten it back? Doctor: Um hum. Not from today but we’ll call ya’. Family Member: Oh yeah. I need to give the nurse the new phone number. Doctor: Oh. Well holler to him. He’ll write it and pass it on to K___ too just in case.

Patient: I’m hanging in there. Doctor: Yeah. What’s new? Patient: Nothing. Doctor: Nothing. Is this one giving you trouble? Doctor: She gives me trouble. I’m glad you qualified. We’re just waiting on the paperwork. patients. Family Member: You can talk. I’m just talking with a patient. Doctor: Didn’t mean to interrupt you. Doctor: The light’s going to stay on? Family Member: She’s upstairs. Doctor: New patient? Family Member: Yep. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Wait at the desk and enjoy the rest of the year. I’ll see you in the early part of next year. Okay? Patient: Alright. Alright. Thank you, Dr. P___, so much. Doctor: No problem. Alright. Very good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know how to find your way out? Patient: Yes Sir. Doctor: Okay. Down the hall to the left, this way, turn left and Healthcare Professional 2: Are you okay? Patient: Does she still need me?

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Right now it must be boiling down there. Michigan is pleasant. Patient: Yeah compared to Kentucky, yes. Doctor: So next week I’m thinking if we get you authorized for this Firmagon injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay I can always cancel if I don’t need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But we need to uh see if the testosterone is not right then I need… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …to get that authorized. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: But that had me going. Doctor: Yeah. Did you have the flu? Patient: I think I had both of them. Doctor: You had? Okay? Because when I had talked to them they just thought about the flu for you, and I didn’t get a conformation. So I just need those records from S___’s. We’ll call over. You think he’s back to his old self at this point? Family Member: Not quite. Doctor: Yeah? Almost? Patient: No. Doctor: Is it just the tiredness still not, not great? Patient: Not really a tiredness but balance a little. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: See I told them last I had that, I had that before. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And they gave me, what was it? Potassium.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - would be which we thought wasn’t really ethnical Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So I think a lot questions may arise after you look at that. Patient: Okay Doctor: Yeah um I don’t think I’ve given you that consent form. first time you’re seeing it. Patient: Okay.That’s yours Okay and this is Doctor: That is a problem as is the … ORIOLE trial. Patient: Okay. And, this is for me? Doctor: That is your copy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: As is this diagram

Patient: Well you took me off of this thing… Doctor: Yes, yes. Family Member: Yes. That’s the other question. Patient: So… Doctor: So we’re gonna try to put you back on. Patient: Okay, that’s fine… Doctor: ‘Cause I don’t think it’s related… Patient: Right. Doctor: …however all these other doctor’s appointments all gotta go right according to plan… Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …so that we don’t make you worse because there’s still no matter what some clearance of you know, any of the medicines are always somewhat cleared, some percentage by the kidneys so… Patient: Right I understand that.

Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: But, it’s usually letters and numbers. Ummm. But, they work in a class of drugs that we think are highly active in prostate cancer, so it’s about five different drugs that are in this space, targeting the same pathway. So, we just don’t know which one has an opening. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And, when would that start? Doctor: M___ will tell us, but probably, you know, obviously in the new year, and it maybe second or third week… Patient: Well, they took seven vials of blood… Doctor: Yes, we did! Patient: Three of them are staying here… Doctor: Mm-hmm. Patient: And we should get the results shortly. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And the other four were going back to the lab, or to the ….
